page.title: 15PLANTLIFE IN THE GREAT PARK
page.content: Conifers grow on the Bagshot Sands in one part of this area, while the London Clay of the other part is best suited for hard wood trees like oak. Some preserved oak trees are more than 1,000 years old. There used to be many elms but they had to be cut down because of Dutch Elm disease. Trees are controlled here; many are planted for quick, commercial return, but oaks remain until they are fully mature. The area reserved for special scientific interest is of great importance because of the rare fungi to be found there on the decaying trees which are left undisturbed. There are relatively few wild flowers because most of the area is kept very tidy. Some of the ground is covered by bracken which behaves like the deciduous trees, sprouting in Spring and dying back in the Autumn.
